I've lived, gone to school, and worked in "socialist" Europe. You don't want to go there. They have slow economic growth, high unemployment, stagnation, and can only compete on the world stage with government subsidies like Airbus. Their students want to come to the US to go to school. They're fighting with the unions to roll back all the entitlements and there are strikes and riots. Efficiency? 15 trips to City Hall to get my resident card for my job. Three years ago they were still using typewriters. Taxes? Two people going for burgers at a Fridays (American chain restaurant) was $75 3 years ago.
 
 As for socialized medicine....On a personal level we really liked our doctor but did you see the movie Schindler's List where the naked women are running in a circle getting chosen for the gas chambers? That's what it feels like to go to a doctor. They don't have to give you a sheet to cover up with when you take your clothes off because they don't think of making you comfortable. It's a different mindset, i.e. not competitive. In England it wasn't cost effective to have doctors in small towns so some people had to drive quite far to go to a doctor. They wouldn't pay for expensive treatments for terminal diseases to keep you alive for what they viewed as short periods of time. The BBC was one of the only English channels we got and there was always a horror story about their medical system on the news. 
 
 Did you listen to Obama's speech about cap and trade. His approach is to make "polluting" energy (which is carbon energy) more expensive than clean energy. But since most of our energy is carbon and clean is expensive or nonexistent, he'll be raising prices for consumers and businesses during a recession. Does that sound like a good idea? What if you're unemployed and struggling and now your energy bills go up? What if you're a business and your higher energy bills make the difference between laying off workers or keeping them?
 
 As for Obama's education agenda...what countries are more competitive than the United States? Didn't you see foreign students in your classes? Were they complaining about the poor quality of our universities? Do you see American students rushing for the exits other than those that leave because they want to learn a foreign language? How many Nobel prizes does our country have? What countries are more advanced in science, medicine, and technology than our own? If you have to have a complicated and dangerous medical operation would you stay in this country or have it elsewhere if money were no object? So spending on education is going to help the economy in a recession? And there's no need to worry about a multitrillion dollar budget?
 
 If you listened carefully to Obama's speech last night, he talked about the jobs his "stimulus" bill has created. Police, teachers, and infrastructure construction...all union, dependent on govt spending, and campaign payback. Not the kind of jobs that would have been created if companies had been encouraged to invest their own money in their businesses. Not the kind that sustain themselves and grow into more jobs as new products and markets develop. Very sad.
